content: Get started tutorial
title: Docker-getting-started

content: å•¥æ˜¯docker is a runnable instance of an image. You can create, start, stop, move, or delete a container using the DockerAPI or CLIï¼ˆå‘½ä»¤è¡Œç•Œé¢ï¼‰. can be run on local machines, virtual machines or deployed to the cloud. is portable (can be run on any OS) Containers are isolated from each other and run their own software, binaries, and configurations.
title: Docker-getting-started

content: 1 The example of â€œBuild the appâ€™s container imageâ€
title: Docker-getting-started

content: 1.1 Get app and Create a Dockerfile 1.1.1 Download the App contents 1.1.2 Create a file named Dockerfile in the same folder as the file package.json with the following contents. # syntax=docker/dockerfile:1FROMnode:12-alpineRUN apk add --no-cache python2 g++ makeWORKDIR/appCOPY . .RUN yarn install --productionCMD ["node", "src/index.js"]
title: Docker-getting-started

content: 1.2 Build the container image docker build -t getting-started . The -t flag tags our image. Named image geting-started The . means that Docker should look for the Dockerfile in the current directory
title: Docker-getting-started

content: 1.3 Start an app container docker run -dp 8080:3000 getting-started -d - run the container in detached mode (in the background) -p 8080:3000 - map port 8080 of the host to port 3000 in the container docker/getting-started - the image to use
title: Docker-getting-started

content: 1.4 use use å§ Add some items If you take a quick look at the Docker Dashboard, you should see your two containers running now (this tutorial and your freshly launched app container).
title: Docker-getting-started

content: 2 Update the application ç›´æ¥æ”¹ï¼Œåˆ äº†åŸæ¥çš„imageï¼Œå†åˆ›å»º
title: Docker-getting-started

content: Remove a container using the CLI Get the ID of the container by using the docker ps command. $ docker ps Use the docker stop command to stop the container. # Swap out <the-container-id> with the ID from docker ps $ docker stop <the-container-id> Once the container has stopped, you can remove it by using the docker rm command. $ docker rm <the-container-id> Note You can stop and remove a container in a single command by adding the â€œforceâ€ flag to the docker rm command. For example: docker rm -f <the-container-id>
title: Docker-getting-started

content: 3 Push the image docker tag getting-started hair2020/getting-started docker push hair2020/getting-started
title: Docker-getting-started
